p: Todd A. DeLong currently serves as a Principal Scientist in the Center for Safety-Critical Systems at the University of Virginia, where he also serves as an adjunct faculty within the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. He received the B.S. degree in Physics & Computer Science from Marietta College in 1987, and the M.S. & Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from the University of Virginia in 1993 & 2002, respectively. His current research interests are: (1) fault-tolerant & safety-critical system design & analysis, and (2) numerical & analytical modeling of computer-based systems.

p: D. Todd Smith is a Professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering at the Virginia Military Institute. Smith received the B.S. degree (1985) from the Virginia Military Institute, the M.S. degree (1986) from Duke University, and the Ph.D. degree (1993) from the University of Virginia all in Electrical Engineering. He is a member of the IEEE, and a member of the IEEE Computer Society, Tau Beta Pi, Sigma Pi Sigma, Phi Kappa Phi, and Eta Kappa Nu. His current research interests are: (1) fault tolerant computing, (2) safety-critical systems, and (3) computer networks.

Barry W. Johnson is a Professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering at the University of Virginia, and is co-founder & co-director of the Center for Safety-Critical Systems. His research & teaching interests include fault-tolerant computing, safety-critical systems, biometrics, and security. Johnson received the B.S. (1979), M.E. (1980), and Ph.D. (1983) degrees in Electrical Engineering from the University of Virginia, Charlottesville. He is a Fellow of the IEEE, and a member of the IEEE Computer Society, Tau Beta Pi, Eta Kappa Nu, and Sigma Xi.

details.abstract: Metrics are commonly used in engineering as measures of the performance of a system for a given attribute. For instance, in the assessment of fault tolerant systems, metrics such as the reliability, R(t) and the Mean Time To Failure (MTTF) are well-accepted as a means to quantify the fault tolerant attributes of a system with an associated failure rate, /spl lambda/. Unfortunately, there does not seem to be a consensus on comparable metrics to use in the assessment of safety-critical systems. The objective of this paper is to develop two metrics that can be used in the assessment of safety-critical systems, the steady-state safety, S/sub ss/, and the Mean Time To Unsafe Failure (MTTUF). S/sub ss/ represents the evaluation of the safety as a function of time, in the limiting case as time approaches infinity. The MTTUF represents the average or mean time that a system will operate safely before a failure that produces an unsafe system state. A 3-state Markov model is used to model a safety-critical system with the transition rates computed as a function of the system coverage C/sub sys/, and the hazard rate /spl lambda/(t). Also, /spl lambda/(t) is defined by the Weibull distribution, primarily because it allows one to easily represent the scenarios where the failure rate is increasing, decreasing, and constant. The results of the paper demonstrate that conservative estimates for lower bounds for both S/sub ss/ & the MTTUF result when C/sub sys/ is assumed to be a constant regardless of the behavior of /spl lambda/(t). The derived results are then used to evaluate three example systems.

The MTTUF is also calculated in [1] using a technique that is based on manipulating the absorbing states of the Markov model, and this result is given asNotice that the two results are almost identical; that is, they differ by approximately \$0.7\times 10^{-3}\%\$.

One advantage of the technique presented in this paper versus the technique presented in [1] is that MTTUF is calculated using standard dependability metrics \$S(t)\$ & \$R(t)\$, and not the manipulation of Markov models.

With the presented technique, safety and/or reliability engineers can estimate MTTUF by using any reliability & safety modeling technique, while the Bukowski & Goble method [1] requires a Markov model.

links.abstract: The authors discuss the notion of conditional MTTF (mean time to failure) and develop an efficient computational method for the absorption probability and conditional MTTF in a finite state-space Markov model. The method requires the solution of two systems of linear equations of size n, where n is the number of transient states in the Markov chain. The concept of cumulative conditional MTTF is introduced and applied to computation of the mean time to critical (unsafe, hazardous) failures.

context.text: Safe is having acceptable risk of the occurrence of a hazard [5].
Risk is the combination of the probability of an abnormal event or failure, and the consequence(s) of that event or failure to a system's components, operators, users, or environment [5].
Hazard is (a) an intrinsic property or condition that has the potential to cause harm or damage, or (b) an existing or potential condition that can result in a mishap [5].
Mishap is an unplanned event or series of events resulting in death, injury, occupational illness, or damage to or loss equipment or property, or damage to the environment [5].

context.text: For instance, in the assessment of fault tolerant systems, metrics such as the reliability, \$R(t)\$, and the MTTF [6] are well-accepted as a means to quantify the fault tolerant attributes of a system with an associated hazard rate, \$\lambda\$.
The system under consideration is stochastic in nature, and as such can be modeled using a Markov model [6].

\$S(t)\$ is the probability that a system will either perform its functions correctly or will discontinue its functions in a manner that does not disrupt the operation of other systems or compromise the safety of any people associated with the system [6].

The transition rate from the Operational State to the Failed-Safe State is \$\lambda(t)C_{sys}\$, and the transition rate from the Operational State to the Failed-Unsafe State is \$\lambda(t)(1-C_{sys})\$. \$\lambda(t)\$ is a function associated with the rate at which the system fails to correctly perform its intended function, and will be defined as the hazard rate function [6].
The probability of being in the Operational State is often defined as the reliability of the system, \$R(t)\$ [6].
